The essay "Macbeth" was previously published as part of Shakespeare : the invention of the human, by Harold Bloom, published by Riverhead in 1998.
Includes the full text of the play, with editorial revisions by Harold Bloom.

by William Shakespeare ; Time life Video ; presented by the British Broadcasting Corporation ; a BBC-Television production in association with Time-Life Television ; produced by Shaun Sutton ; directed by Jack Gold.
Originally produced for television broadcast in 1982.
Title from title frames on streaming video.
Access limited to UNC Chapel Hill-authenticated users.
Script editor, David Snodin ; music, Carl Davis.
Nicol Williamson, Ian Hogg, Jane Lapotaire, Tony Doyle.

Driven by ambition and an unscrupulous wife, Macbeth murders the King of Scotland and claims the throne for himself. Haunted by ghosts and vexed by witches, he and his wife descend into the depths of madness and paranoia as they crumble beneath the weight of their crimes.
System requirements: Web browser with Adobe Flash player extension.
Closed captioned for the hearing impaired.
Streaming video available via the UNC-Chapel Hill Libraries

The genuine account of the trial of Eugene Aram, for the murder of Daniel Clark, late of Knaresbrough, in the county of York, who was convicted at York assizes, August 3, 1759, before the Honourable William Noel, Esq., one of His Majesty's justices of the Court of Common Pleas

to which, after a short narration of the fact is prefixed, an account of the remarkable discovery of the human skeleton at St. Robert's cave, where it had lain upwards of thirteen years, a detail of all the judicial proceedings from the time of the bones being found, to the commitment of Richard Houseman, Eugene Aram, and Henry Terry to York-Castle, the depositions of Anna Aram, Philip Coates, John Yates, &c., the examination and confession of Richard Houseman, the apprehending of Eugene Aram, at Lynn, in Norfolk, with his examination and commitment : to which are added, the remarkable defence he made on his trial, his own account of himself, written after his condemnation, with the apology, which he left in his cell, for the attempt he made on his own life : all taken immediately from the original depositions, papers, &c.
Reproduction of the original from Harvard Law School Library.
Gale, a part of Cengage Learning,
Available via the World Wide Web.

Originally issued in parts; the first "livraison" was announced in the Bibliographie de la France 5 Sept. 1827; the second. third & fourth were announced 16 Aug. 1828, apparently issued together.
Free translations from the authors named in title; includes Schiller's Don Karlos, Shakespeare's Macbeth, and act 5 from Alfrieri's Bruto Primo.

the tragedies-- Hamlet, Macbeth, Romeo and Juliet, and Julius Caesar /
[construction and photography by John McCann ; edited and narrated by Monica Sweeney, and Becky Thomas.]
Whimsical visual adaptations of four Shakespearean tragedies, rendered in LEGO bricks, feature scene-by-scene reenactments accompanied by captioned excerpts from the plays.
